subject: RE: [junit] novice QA
msgSnippet: If you refactor your class to have this template: public class validator () { protected List validate (Class cls) { ... } protected PrintStream print
messageBody:
If you refactor your class to have this template:

public class validator () {
protected List validate (Class cls) { ... }
protected PrintStream print (SpecificError error) { ...}
}

it is then really easy to test. Your class can implement other methods that use these two methods for testing.

You have two possibilities:
- test for all errors in one test
- test for one error in each test

I would first test the most global case and then, if you found problems (or if you want to be more confident) you can write more specific tests.

Define an inner class that fires all possible errors. Your test method looks like:

public void testFireAllErrors () {
ClassFiresAllErrors temp = new ClassFiresAllError();
List result = myValidator.validate(ClassErrorX);
assertTrue(result.size() == X /* number of possible errors */);
assertTrue(result.contains(new ErrorX());
assertTrue(result.contains(new ErrorY());
...
 }

Now to test the print method: list all errors that can be reported. For each error, write a test method

public void testPrintErrorX () {
PrintStream stream = myValidator.print(new SpecificError(X));
assertEquals(stream.toString(), "...what the error should print...");
}
